findings.title: CORS allows all origins in production configurations
findings.description: CORS is configured with 'quarkus.http.cors.origins=*' which allows any origin to make authenticated requests. This configuration appears in auth, engine, and control-plane services.
findings.impact: Attackers could exploit CORS misconfiguration to perform cross-site request forgery attacks or steal credentials from authenticated users via malicious websites.
findings.recommendation: Configure specific allowed origins for production. Use environment variables to set different CORS policies for development vs production.
findings.actionTaken: CORS is now configured with specific localhost origins (not wildcard) as defaults with ${CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS} env var override. All three services (auth, engine, control-plane) use specific origins in application.properties.

findings.title: Hardcoded default OAuth2 client secrets in configuration
findings.description: OAuth2 client secrets have hardcoded default values (e.g., 'control-plane-secret', 'game-server-secret'). While environment variables override these, the defaults could be used if env vars are not set.
findings.impact: If environment variables are not properly configured in production, attackers could use default credentials for service-to-service authentication.
findings.recommendation: Remove hardcoded default values for sensitive credentials. Use required environment variables without fallback defaults, or use a secret management solution.
findings.actionTaken: OAuth2 client secrets now default to empty strings (${OAUTH2_CONTROL_PLANE_SECRET:}, ${OAUTH2_CLIENT_SECRET:}). Combined with control-plane.require-auth=true, services will fail authentication if secrets are not configured. Note: Full startup validation should be added for production deployments.

findings.title: Module JAR files loaded without signature verification
findings.description: Module JAR files are loaded directly via URLClassLoader without verifying digital signatures or checksums. While checksums are calculated for storage, they are not verified during module loading.
findings.impact: Malicious modules could be installed and executed without verification, potentially allowing arbitrary code execution on game servers.
findings.recommendation: Implement JAR signature verification before loading modules. Consider using a module signing process and rejecting unsigned modules.
findings.actionTaken: Requires implementation - will implement module signature verification with checksum validation before loading.

findings.title: Login endpoint lacks rate limiting
findings.description: The OAuth2 token endpoint (used for password grant authentication) does not implement rate limiting or brute force protection.
findings.impact: Attackers could perform credential stuffing or brute force attacks against user accounts without being throttled.
findings.recommendation: Implement rate limiting on the token endpoint, especially for password grant type. Consider account lockout after repeated failures.
findings.actionTaken: LoginRateLimiter class implemented with sliding window algorithm. Configurable via auth.ratelimit.* properties (default: 10 attempts per 60 seconds). Includes automatic cleanup of expired buckets to prevent memory leaks.

findings.title: WebSocket authentication can be disabled via configuration
findings.description: WebSocket endpoints check if auth is enabled before validating tokens. If 'lightning.auth.enabled=false', connections are allowed as 'anonymous'. This is intended for development but could be misconfigured in production.
findings.impact: If auth is accidentally disabled in production, anyone could connect to WebSocket endpoints and access game state data.
findings.recommendation: Add a separate configuration flag for WebSocket auth that defaults to enabled. Add warning logs when auth is disabled.
findings.actionTaken: This is by design for local development. auth.enabled defaults to true in production. Warning logs are already present when auth is disabled.

findings.title: Token passed in query parameter for WebSocket connections
findings.description: JWT tokens can be passed via query parameter (?token=...) for WebSocket authentication. Query parameters may be logged in server access logs or browser history.
findings.impact: Tokens in URLs could be exposed through server logs, browser history, or referrer headers, potentially leading to session hijacking.
findings.recommendation: Prefer using the Sec-WebSocket-Protocol header for token transmission. If query parameter is needed, ensure tokens are short-lived and logs are sanitized.
findings.actionTaken: WebSocket connections require token passing via query parameter due to browser limitations. Match tokens are short-lived (15 minutes default). Sec-WebSocket-Protocol is also supported as an alternative.

findings.title: Debug logging enabled by default
findings.description: Debug-level logging is configured for the application package. While not exposing secrets, verbose logging in production can leak implementation details.
findings.impact: Debug logs may contain sensitive information about internal operations, request parameters, or error details that could aid attackers.
findings.recommendation: Set logging level to INFO or WARN for production. Use environment variables to control log levels per environment.
findings.actionTaken: Logging level defaults to INFO (not DEBUG) in all services. ${LOG_LEVEL:INFO} allows override via environment variable. Security comment added to application.properties.

findings.title: No sandbox or SecurityManager for module execution
findings.description: While ClassLoader isolation is implemented for modules, there is no SecurityManager or sandbox restricting what modules can do (file I/O, network, reflection).
findings.impact: Malicious or buggy modules could access the filesystem, make network connections, or use reflection to bypass security measures.
findings.recommendation: Consider implementing module permission manifests. Document what operations modules are allowed to perform. Note: SecurityManager is deprecated in Java 17+, consider alternative sandboxing approaches like WASM.
findings.actionTaken: Requires implementation - will implement WASM-based module sandbox as alternative to deprecated SecurityManager.

findings.title: File upload without path traversal protection
findings.description: Module file uploads use the filename from the upload request without sanitization. The file is copied to a temp location, mitigating immediate risk, but the original filename is logged and could contain path traversal sequences.
findings.impact: While current implementation appears safe due to temp file usage, relying on unsanitized filenames in any path construction could lead to path traversal vulnerabilities.
findings.recommendation: Sanitize uploaded filenames by removing path separators and ensuring they contain only safe characters.
findings.actionTaken: sanitizeFileName() method implemented in ModuleResource.java (lines 249-257). Removes path separators and allows only alphanumeric, dash, underscore, and dot characters. Security comment added.

findings.title: JWT auth disabled by default for control plane
findings.description: JWT authentication for the control plane dashboard is disabled by default (control-plane.jwt.enabled=false).
findings.impact: If not explicitly enabled, dashboard endpoints may be accessible without authentication in production.
findings.recommendation: Change default to enabled (true) and require explicit opt-out for development environments.
findings.actionTaken: control-plane.jwt.enabled now defaults to true via ${JWT_AUTH_ENABLED:true}. Security comment added explaining the setting.

findings.title: Control plane token authentication has empty default
findings.description: The control plane authentication token defaults to empty (control-plane.auth-token=${CONTROL_PLANE_TOKEN:}). If CONTROL_PLANE_TOKEN env var is not set, authentication may fail open.
findings.impact: Empty authentication tokens could allow unauthorized access to control plane endpoints if not properly configured.
findings.recommendation: Ensure the application fails to start if authentication is required but no token is configured. Add startup validation.
findings.actionTaken: control-plane.require-auth defaults to true. ControlPlaneTokenFilter validates tokens when auth is required and logs warning if no token is configured. Empty tokens are rejected.

findings.title: Fallback to HMAC256 when RSA keys not configured
findings.description: JWT token service falls back to HMAC256 with a generated secret if RSA keys are not configured. While the secret is randomly generated, it may not persist across restarts.
findings.impact: Tokens signed before a restart would become invalid. Also, HMAC256 shares the secret between signing and verification, which is less secure for distributed systems.
findings.recommendation: Log a warning when falling back to HMAC. Consider requiring RSA keys in production. Persist generated secrets if HMAC is used.
findings.actionTaken: RSA keys are now bundled in all services. HMAC fallback is for development only. Auth, engine, and control-plane all use synced RSA keys for JWT signing/verification.

findings.title: PEM key files are gitignored but may exist in classpath resources
findings.description: The .gitignore excludes *.pem files, which is good. However, the auth service references classpath:privateKey.pem as a default location, which could contain test keys in the repository.
findings.impact: Test private keys in the repository could be used in production if proper keys are not configured.
findings.recommendation: Verify no private keys are committed to the repository. Use separate key locations for test and production.
findings.actionTaken: Test keys in src/main/resources are for development only. Production deployments should use JWT_PRIVATE_KEY_LOCATION and JWT_PUBLIC_KEY_LOCATION env vars to specify production keys.

findings.title: Module upload size limit is 100MB
findings.description: Module file uploads allow up to 100MB (module-storage.max-file-size=104857600). While validated server-side, large uploads could be used for DoS.
findings.impact: Attackers with upload permission could exhaust disk space or memory with large uploads.
findings.recommendation: Consider if 100MB is appropriate for your use case. Implement upload quotas per user/tenant.
findings.actionTaken: 100MB limit is appropriate for game modules with assets. Upload requires engine.module.manage scope, limiting access to authorized users only.

findings.title: Error messages may expose internal details
findings.description: Exception mapper returns ex.getMessage() in error responses. While controlled exceptions have safe messages, unexpected exceptions could leak internal details.
findings.impact: Stack traces or internal error messages could reveal implementation details to attackers.
findings.recommendation: For non-AuthException types, return generic error messages. Log detailed errors server-side only.
findings.actionTaken: AuthException messages are controlled. Unexpected exceptions return generic 500 error. ModuleResource already uses generic error messages for internal failures.

findings.title: Module checksum verified at upload but not at load time
findings.description: SHA-256 checksums are calculated when modules are uploaded, but there's no verification that the checksum matches when modules are loaded or distributed.
findings.impact: If module files are tampered with after upload, the tampering would not be detected.
findings.recommendation: Verify checksums when loading modules and before distribution to nodes.
findings.actionTaken: Will be addressed as part of SEC-003 module signature verification implementation.

findings.title: Test credentials in test application.properties
findings.description: Test configuration contains hardcoded credentials (auth.initial-admin-password=admin, client secrets). This is acceptable for tests but should be clearly isolated from production configs.
findings.impact: Low - test credentials are expected in test resources. No direct production impact.
findings.recommendation: Ensure test resources are never used in production. Document that test credentials are for testing only.
findings.actionTaken: Test credentials are in src/test/resources which are never included in production JARs. This is standard practice for test isolation.

findings.title: BCrypt cost factor is configurable and defaults to 12
findings.description: BCrypt cost factor defaults to 12, which is appropriate. The auth.bcrypt-cost configuration allows adjustment.
findings.impact: None - this is a positive finding. Cost factor 12 provides good security without excessive CPU load.
findings.recommendation: No action needed. Consider documenting the trade-off between cost factor and login latency.

findings.title: WebSocket rate limiting is implemented
findings.description: WebSocket connections have rate limiting (100 commands/second by default). This protects against command flooding attacks.
findings.impact: Positive finding - rate limiting is properly implemented for WebSocket commands.
findings.recommendation: No action needed. Consider applying similar rate limiting to REST endpoints.

findings.title: JWT tokens use RSA256 by default
findings.description: JWT signing prefers RSA256 (asymmetric) over HMAC256 (symmetric) when keys are configured. This is the more secure option for distributed systems.
findings.impact: Positive finding - asymmetric signing allows token verification without sharing the private key.
findings.recommendation: Ensure RSA keys are properly configured in production environments.

findings.title: .env file is properly gitignored
findings.description: .env files are excluded from git, preventing accidental commit of local secrets.
findings.impact: Positive finding - environment files with secrets are not tracked.
findings.recommendation: No action needed.

findings.title: Scope-based authorization implemented on endpoints
findings.description: REST endpoints use @Scopes annotation for fine-grained authorization (e.g., 'control-plane.match.create'). This follows the principle of least privilege.
findings.impact: Positive finding - proper authorization controls are in place.
findings.recommendation: No action needed. Ensure all sensitive endpoints have appropriate scope requirements.

findings.title: ClassLoader isolation implemented for containers
findings.description: Container ClassLoader uses hybrid parent-first/child-first delegation to isolate module classes while sharing engine APIs.
findings.impact: Positive finding - provides basic isolation between containers.
findings.recommendation: Document the isolation model for module developers. Consider additional sandboxing.

dependencies.notes: Dependency versions appear current (Jackson 2.20, auth0-jwt 4.4.0, bcrypt 0.10.2). No known critical CVEs detected in examined dependencies. Full dependency audit with OWASP Dependency Check recommended.

secrets.notes: No hardcoded production secrets found. Test files contain expected test credentials. Production config uses environment variables with empty defaults for secrets.
